descriptionSet.description: On this advertisement for Brooke Bond Tea, a colourful pigeon can be seen carrying a box of "Brooke Bond Tea" on her back. Her wings are green and look like tea-leaves.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: Brooke Bond's A-1 Dust Tea Advertisement

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Brooke Bond Tea
text-en: Brooke Bond A-1 Dust Tea
text-hi: बढ़िया चाय की ज़्यादा प्यालियाँ
description-en: On this advertisement for Brooke Bond Tea, a colourful pigeon can be seen carrying a box of "Brooke Bond Tea" on her back. Her wings are green and look like tea-leaves. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Soon, CTC-leaf tea (a.k.a. "mamri" tea), mainly produced in Assam, became abundantly available in bulk in retail shops that proliferated in urban areas, and was also packaged as such widely-recognized "All-India" brands as Lipton "Yellow Label" or Brooke Bond "Red Label" (the Hindi slogan in this image emphasizes economy, boasting that "Each packet contains more leaves to produce superior chai!"). It also helped spark the expansion of chai stalls and shops—new spaces for (especially) male camaraderie and the exchange of news, gossip, and opinions—as well as the growing adoption of kaṛak ("strong, flavorful") chai as a domestically-produced beverage, suitable for consumption at all hours of the day, and the de rigeur hospitality offering to visitors, especially in mid-to-late afternoon— usually accompanied by biscuits and savories (cāy-vāy, "tea and so forth"). (Philip Lutgendorf)(gs)
